author: markekraus
body:
The seemingly only useful way to use the Type Information currently added by default during `Export-Csv` would be to reapply the PSTypeNames to the PSCustomObjects. Currently, These Type names are currently prepended with `CSV:`. This means that exporting a simple PSObject to CSV and then re-importing would require 2 format definitions or add/set the PSTypeNames for the imported objects.


Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
[PSCustomObject]@{
    PSTypeName = 'My.Custom.Object'
    Column1 = 'values1'
} | Export-Csv C:\temp\csv.csv
$import = Import-Csv C:\temp\csv.csv
$import.PSObject.TypeNames
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
My.Custom.Object
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
CSV:My.Custom.Object
```

Environment data
----------------

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.0-beta.8
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-beta.8
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.15063
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: You could have `My.Custom.Object` as TypesNames[0] and `CSV:My.Custom.Object` as TypesNames[1] although I don't know if anyone actually depends on `CSV:typename`.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @PowerShell/powershell-committee reviewed this and ok with a small breaking change where we insert the desired typename in index 0 and add the CSV:typename as index 1.

title: Import-Csv Should apply PSTypeNames uppon import when Type Information is present in the CSV
